entry.title: Paths, curves, and trajectories
entry.content:
A list of sources to study while thinking about implementing a smooth trail for a player in the gravity-based XOnix remake vonix.

  • Piecewise Bezier Curves Path Planning with Continuous Curvature Constraint for Autonomous Driving
  • Collision-free and Smooth Trajectory Computation in Cluttered Environments
  • Fast Smoothing of Motion Planning Trajectories using B-Splines
  • Fast Smoothing of Manipulator Trajectories using Optimal Bounded-Acceleration Shortcuts
  • HTML5 Canvas Bezier Curve Tutorial
  • HTML5 Canvas Path Tutorial
  • Curve and Circular Movement
  • Fluid curves with Smooth.js and HTML5 canvas

Basically the idea is that at any given time we can compute the path a player is going to take if nothing acts upon him. Knowing that path, we can draw the trail behind him as times goes on and he advances. If something acts on the player, then we re-compute the path, and from the point when something acted on him, use the new path to draw the trail.

Paths, curves, and trajectories was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on February 26, 2014.

entry.title: Languages I want to learn
entry.content:
In the order of most important, from the point of view of work. I want to know these languages at an advanced level.

  • Python

Python is a programming language that lets you work quickly and integrate systems more effectively.

  • Ruby

Ruby is … A dynamic, open source programming language with a focus on simplicity and productivity. It has an elegant syntax that is natural to read and easy to write.

  • Go

Go is an open source programming language that makes it easy to build simple, reliable, and efficient software.

  • Emacs Lisp

Emacs Lisp is a dialect of the Lisp programming language used by the GNU Emacs and XEmacs text editors.

Languages I want to learn was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on February 25, 2014.

entry.title: The current state of things
entry.content:
I am at work. It seems that everything is calm; got to work in a normal fashion. Today is a reading day.

Starting to work!

I have slept today to heart’s content! I should do so more often. There is an absolute clearness in my head, I am not yawning, the eyes are wide open. Today I will read English literature, and should also read some Russian.

To write, one must read, read, read!

The current state of things was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on February 21, 2014.

entry.title: SCSS and CoffeeScript for Emacs
entry.content:
SCSS

Sass is the most mature, stable, and powerful professional grade CSS extension language in the world.

CoffeeScript

CoffeeScript is a little language that compiles into JavaScript. Underneath that awkward Java-esque patina, JavaScript has always had a gorgeous heart. CoffeeScript is an attempt to expose the good parts of JavaScript in a simple way.

Thanks to the following resources:

  • sass-mode
  • coffee-mode

I now have an Emacs that highlights for me .scss and .coffee files.

= )

SCSS and CoffeeScript for Emacs was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on February 14, 2014.

entry.title: Group theory related question
entry.content:
On Mathematics Stack Exchange I have posed the following question:

I am currently studying the manuscript Group Theory: A First Journey by Vipul Naik. It is available from the web page http://www.cmi.ac.in/~vipul/mathjourneys/ . In this manuscript the author proposes the following question:

Suppose the ordering of the elements in the rows and columns is the same. Then what kind of multiplication table would a magma have if it were to be a group? More generally, what are the constraints on the multiplication table corresponding to each of the properties that we can talk of for a binary operation?

After reading the comments and the answers made by other users, I began to understand what the author is asking. He wants the reader to think how would a multiplication matrix look like for a magma that follows the 3 requirements of a group. Maybe not look like, but what properties, patterns, etc. it would exhibit.

Group theory related question was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on February 07, 2014.

entry.title: Retrieving title of a site
entry.content:
Given a URL, use Node.js to retrieve the site’s title. On a Linux system we have a powerful utility wget. Combining that with a JavaScript regex expression, we can easily retrieve a title from a given URL.

entry.title: Bookmarks manager hosted on GitHub
entry.content:
bookmarks seems like a nice starting point. Things to do:

  • add tags, search by tags
  • allow hierarchy of tags (sort of like directories)
  • don’t display all bookmarks on one page
  • allow easy edit with text editor of file with bookmarks
  • import and append from Firefox, Chrome, Safari, Opera, IE
  • locally, web GUI for CRUD operations on bookmarks
  • allow for using custom themes to display bookmarks
  • preview for a link (an image overlay)

Back-end could be Node.js based. Front-end could be AngularJS based. Preview could be done with PhantomJS (Phantomjs - take screenshot of a web page).

Sounds like fun ^_^v!

Bookmarks manager hosted on GitHub was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on January 31, 2014.

entry.title: MathJax tests
entry.content:
MathJax is an open source JavaScript display engine for mathematics that works in all browsers. Some examples of what it can do are provided below. Oh, and I wanto to point out how very awesome is it that the markdown processor kramdown used on Nintoku supports math natively.

Inside p tag

When $a \ne 0$, there are two solutions to \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) and they are $$x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.$$

Inside span tag

When $a \ne 0$, there are two solutions to (ax^2 + bx + c = 0) and they are

Inside div tag

When $a \ne 0$, there are two solutions to \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) and they are $$x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.$$

Not in a tag

When $a \ne 0$, there are two solutions to (ax^2 + bx + c = 0) and they are

Now, we will use double dollar signs to surround math stuff.

Inside p tag

When $$ $a \ne 0$ $$, there are two solutions to $$ \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) $$ and they are $$x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.$$

Inside span tag

When , there are two solutions to and they are

Inside div tag

When $$ $a \ne 0$ $$, there are two solutions to $$ \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) $$ and they are $$x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.$$

Not in a tag

When , there are two solutions to and they are

And the proper way is:

When \(a \ne 0\), there are two solutions to \(ax^2 + bx + c = 0\) and they are $$x = {-b \pm \sqrt{b^2-4ac} \over 2a}.$$ This is really cool!

MathJax tests was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on January 30, 2014.

entry.title: Lagrange's Theorem
entry.content:
In his 1771 paper Réflexions sur la résolution algébrique des équations, Lagrange was studying polynomials. In particular he was interested in polynomials of degree 5 and higher. This was the ground work that was used later on by Galois to put forth the beginning of Galois theory.

Lagrange's Theorem was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on January 29, 2014.

entry.title: A Group
entry.content:
A group G is a collection of objects with an operation satisfying the following rules (axioms).

Today I realized that the operation is actually what defines a group, NOT the collection of objects. A collection of object is not a group (of objects) as I previously thought (probably because I was making a connection between the English meaning of the word group and the mathematical term group). Also, a group can lose it’s status if it’s operation changes but the collection of objects remains the same (if some of the axioms stop being true for the new operation).

A Group was originally published by Valera Rozuvan at Nintoku on January 28, 2014.

entry.title: Extraordinary worlds in mathematics
entry.content:
More and more these days I stumble upon something very intriguing in mathematics. Whole unknown worlds created by exceptional mathematicians. Not some ancient theories which are centuries old. Novel concepts, reasoning, and imagination. Take a look at the Inter-universal Teichmüller theory.

entry.title: A simple bus time schedule application.
entry.content:
Today at my company we discussed possible small project’s we can work on in our spare time. The idea of creating an application to display the most up-to-date bus schedule was most appealing. It will have an iPhone, Android, and Web interface. The plan is to maintain it as an open-source application hosted on GitHub.
